message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Spreading dynamics of information on online social networks
Paper Abstract: Social media is profoundly changing our society with its unprecedented spreading power. Due to the complexity of human behaviors and the diversity of massive messages, the information-spreading dynamics are complicated, and the reported mechanisms are different and even controversial. Based on data from mainstream social media platforms, including WeChat, Weibo, and Twitter, cumulatively encompassing a total of 7.45 billion users, we uncover a ubiquitous mechanism that the information-spreading dynamics are basically driven by the interplay of social reinforcement and social weakening effects. Accordingly, we propose a concise equation, which, surprisingly, can well describe all the empirical large-scale spreading trajectories. Our theory resolves a number of controversial claims and satisfactorily explains many phenomena previously observed. It also reveals that the highly clustered nature of social networks can lead to rapid and high-frequency information bursts with relatively small coverage per burst. This vital feature enables social media to have a high capacity and diversity for information dissemination, beneficial for its ecological development.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## WeChat Overview

WeChat is an instant messaging, social media, and mobile payment app developed by Tencent.(no content)First released in 2011, it became the world's largest standalone mobile app in 2018 with over 1 billion monthly active users.

### Key Features

WeChat provides text messaging, hold-to-talk voice messaging, broadcast messaging, video conferencing, video games, mobile payment, sharing of photographs and videos and location sharing.(no content)The Chinese version of WeChat, Weixin, has been described as China's "app for everything" and a super-app because of its wide range of functions.

### User Base

As of January 2022, it was reported that WeChat has more than 1.2 billion users.(no content)By 2018, WeChat had been used by 93.5% of Chinese internet users.

### WeChat Pay

WeChat Pay is a digital wallet service incorporated into WeChat, which allows users to perform mobile payments and send money between contacts.(no content)In 2014, for Chinese New Year, WeChat introduced a feature for distributing virtual red envelopes, which allows users to send money to contacts and groups as gifts.

Based on the search results, here's information about Weibo:

## Weibo (Social Media Platform)

Weibo, or Sina Weibo, is a Chinese microblogging website.(no content)Launched by Sina Corporation on 14 August 2009, it is one of the biggest social media platforms in China, with over 582 million monthly active users (252 million daily active users) as of Q1 2022.

### Key Features
Through the website or the mobile app, users can upload pictures and videos publicly for instant sharing, with other users being able to comment with text, pictures and videos.(no content)To avoid the impersonation of celebrities, Sina Weibo uses verification symbols; celebrity accounts have an orange letter "V" and organizations' accounts have a blue letter "V".

### Company History
In March 2014, Sina announced a spinoff of Weibo and filed an IPO under the symbol WB. Sina carved out 11% of Weibo in the IPO, with Alibaba owning 32% post-IPO. The company began trading publicly on 17 April 2014.

### Notable Aspects
The platform has been highly successful but has faced criticism for heavy censorship.(no content)Despite fierce competition among Chinese social media platforms, Sina Weibo remains the most popular.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social media:

## Definition and Purpose

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn. More specifically, social media includes "forms of electronic communication (such as websites for social networking and microblogging) through which users create online communities to share information, ideas, personal messages, and other content (such as videos)."

## Key Features

These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.(no content)Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Popular Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.

## Global Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

## Business Applications

Social media marketing is the use of social media platforms and websites to promote a product or service.(no content)In 2014, over 80% of business executives identified social media as an integral part of their business.

## Concerns and Criticisms

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about social media:

## Definition and Purpose

Social media is used to share memories, form friendships, build communities and learn. More specifically, social media includes "forms of electronic communication (such as websites for social networking and microblogging) through which users create online communities to share information, ideas, personal messages, and other content (such as videos)."

## Key Features

These interactive platforms allow individuals, communities, businesses, and organizations to share, co-create, discuss, participate in, and modify user-generated or self-curated content.(no content)Social media outlets operate in a dialogic transmission system (many sources to many receivers) while traditional media operate under a monologic transmission model (one source to many receivers).

## Popular Platforms

Popular social media platforms with over 100 million registered users include Twitter, Facebook, WeChat, ShareChat, Instagram, Pinterest, QZone, Weibo, VK, Tumblr, Baidu Tieba, Threads and LinkedIn.

## Global Usage

As of 2023, as many as 4.76 billion people used social media some 59% of the global population.

## Business Applications

Social media marketing is the use of social media platforms and websites to promote a product or service.(no content)In 2014, over 80% of business executives identified social media as an integral part of their business.

## Concerns and Criticisms

Social media has been criticized for a range of negative impacts on children and teenagers, including exposure to inappropriate content, exploitation by adults, sleep problems, attention problems, feelings of exclusion, and various mental health maladies.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Information diffusion"

Links: [{"title":"Diffusion of innovations - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_of_innovations"},{"title":"Sociological theory of diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sociological_theory_of_diffusion"},{"title":"Diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion"},{"title":"Information cascade - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_cascade"},{"title":"Confusion and diffusion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Confusion_and_diffusion"},{"title":"Alex Bavelas - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alex_Bavelas"},{"title":"Diffusion (business) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_(business)"},{"title":"Diffusion process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffusion_process"},{"title":"Everett Rogers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Everett_Rogers"},{"title":"Latent diffusion model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latent_Diffusion_Model"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about information diffusion:

## Overview

Diffusion of innovations is a theory that seeks to explain how, why, and at what rate new ideas and technology spread.(no content)The theory was popularized by Everett Rogers in his book Diffusion of Innovations, first published in 1962, in which Rogers argues that diffusion is the process by which an innovation is communicated through certain channels over time among the participants in a social system.

## Key Components

Rogers proposes that five main elements influence the spread of a new idea: the innovation itself, adopters, communication channels, time, and a social system.

## Categories of Adopters

Rogers proposes that adopters of any new innovation or idea can be categorized as innovators (2.5%), early adopters (13.5%), early majority (34%), late majority (34%) and laggards (16%), based on the mathematically based Bell curve.

## Related Concepts

Diffusion of information and ideas has been categorized into two modes: Internal diffusion is the spread of information and innovations within a network, flowing within a single adopting population – a given industry or geographical network.(no content)Not all individuals exert an equal amount of influence over others; opinion leaders are influential in spreading either positive or negative information about an innovation.

## Network Effects

Studies have focused on information diffusion within a small group and on network structures that affect the speed and efficiency of this information diffusion.

I found comprehensive information about Twitter/X. Here's an overview:

## Overview

X, formerly known as Twitter, is an American microblogging and social networking service.(no content)It is one of the world's largest social media platforms and one of the most-visited websites.

## Origin and Development

Work on the project started in February 2006, and the first Twitter prototype, developed by Dorsey and contractor Florian Weber, was used as an internal service for Odeo employees, with the full version introduced publicly on July 15, 2006.(no content)Twitter spun off into its own company in April 2007, and the tipping point for Twitter's popularity was the 2007 South by Southwest Interactive (SXSWi) conference, during which Twitter usage increased from 20,000 tweets per day to 60,000.

## Ownership Changes

The service is owned by the American company X Corp., which was established to succeed the prior owner Twitter, Inc. in March 2023 following the October 2022 acquisition of Twitter by Elon Musk for US$44 billion.(no content)In March 2025, X Corp. was acquired by xAI, Musk's artificial intelligence company, in an all-stock transaction valued at $33 billion, with a full valuation of $45 billion when factoring in $12 billion in debt.

## Rebranding

In July 2023, Musk announced that Twitter would be rebranded to "X" and the bird logo would be retired, a process which was completed by May 2024.

Web search results for query: "Social network"

Links: [{"title":"Social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network"},{"title":"The Social Network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Network"},{"title":"Social networking service - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_networking_service"},{"title":"Social media - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_media"},{"title":"List of social networking services - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_social_networking_services"},{"title":"Social network analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network_analysis"},{"title":"Distributed social network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_social_network"},{"title":"Gab (social network) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gab.com"},{"title":"Social Networks (journal) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_Networks_(journal)"},{"title":"The Social Reckoning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Social_Reckoning"}]

Here are the search results for "Social network":

## Definition and Overview

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.

## Social Networking Services

A social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.(no content)Social networking sites provide websites that facilitate the building of a network of contacts in order to exchange various types of content online.

## History

Early social networking on the World Wide Web began in the form of generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), many of which focused on bringing people together to interact with each other through chat rooms and encouraged users to share personal information and ideas via personal web pages.(no content)A newer generation of social networking sites began to flourish with the emergence of SixDegrees in 1997, Open Diary in 1998, Mixi in 1999, Makeoutclub in 2000, Cyworld in 2001, Hub Culture in 2002, and Friendster and Nexopia in 2003.(no content)MySpace and LinkedIn were launched in 2003, and Bebo was launched in 2005.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

Here are the search results for "Social network":

## Definition and Overview

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.

## Social Networking Services

A social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.(no content)Social networking sites provide websites that facilitate the building of a network of contacts in order to exchange various types of content online.

## History

Early social networking on the World Wide Web began in the form of generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), many of which focused on bringing people together to interact with each other through chat rooms and encouraged users to share personal information and ideas via personal web pages.(no content)A newer generation of social networking sites began to flourish with the emergence of SixDegrees in 1997, Open Diary in 1998, Mixi in 1999, Makeoutclub in 2000, Cyworld in 2001, Hub Culture in 2002, and Friendster and Nexopia in 2003.(no content)MySpace and LinkedIn were launched in 2003, and Bebo was launched in 2005.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and the ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

I've completed the web search for "Social reinforcement psychology." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Reinforcement is a basic term in operant conditioning.(no content)Positive reinforcement occurs when a desirable event or stimulus is presented as a consequence of a behavior and the chance that this behavior will manifest in similar environments increases.

## Social Aspects of Reinforcement

Several theories connect reinforcement to social contexts:

**Social Learning Theory**: Social learning theory is a psychological theory of social behavior that explains how people acquire new behaviors, attitudes, and emotional reactions through observing and imitating others.(no content)Learning also occurs through the observation of rewards and punishments, a process known as vicarious reinforcement.

**Social Cognitive Theory**: Reinforcements encompass both internal and external responses to an individual's behavior, influencing the probability of either sustaining or ceasing the behavior, and these reinforcements may originate from within the individual or the external environment and can take the form of either positive or negative outcomes.

**Social Conditioning**: Social conditioning is formed by the creation of 'good' and 'bad' behaviors - persistent reinforcement and the use of operant conditioning influences individuals/groups to develop particular behaviors and/or ideals.

**Communal Reinforcement**: Communal reinforcement is a social phenomenon in which a concept or idea is repeatedly asserted in a community, regardless of whether sufficient empirical evidence has been presented to support it.

These concepts show how social environments and group dynamics play crucial roles in how reinforcement shapes human behavior.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
